author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Burning Man 2023: What We Know
description: Thousands of people were stuck at the Burning Man festival in Nevada this weekend because of rain and mud. It was not clear when, or how, attendees would get out.
content: Thousands of attendees of the Burning Man festival in the Nevada desert were stuck there on Sunday after heavy rain on Friday night led officials to close the road that leads in and out of the makeshift town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Liberating? Exploitative? A Nude Scene Summer Report Card.
description: From “The Idol” to “Oppenheimer,” women’s bodies were on display on our screens the past few months. Some executions succeeded with humor, others felt misguided.
content: This has been a summer of women being liberated — from their wardrobes, mostly. The nudity on our screens has been a topic of constant conversation for months, from the provoking premiere of “The Idol” in June to the left-field nudity in “Oppenheimer” (and the interpersonal havoc it wreaked on some relationships, as one viral TikTok can attest to). In each instance the theme, in one respect or another, seems to be liberation: not necessarily of the de Beauvoir variety, but a female character’s liberation from some kind of enclosure, whether societal, cultural or personal, and her nudity is meant to reflect that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: The Never-Ending Nightmare of Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
description: Environmentally, economically and in terms of pure human suffering, the destruction of the Kakhovka dam unleashed untold damage. Months later, many communities are still reeling.
content: Sunset along the Kakhovka Reservoir in central Ukraine, especially in summer, used to be gorgeous: kids played in the shallow water near the shore, men fished and young couples walked under the pine trees as the last traces of sunlight reflected off the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: New York’s Migrant Crisis Is Growing. So Are Democrats’ Anxieties.
description: The influx of asylum seekers has the makings of a potent political force, and Republicans are ready to test it in key 2024 house races.
content: Republicans successfully made crime the defining issue of the 2022 midterm elections in New York, fanning fears about public safety to rout suburban Democrats and help secure the party its House majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Long Covid Poses Special Challenges for Seniors
description: Older people are less likely to be diagnosed but more likely to experience certain kinds of illnesses, research suggests.
content: Ask Patricia Anderson how she is doing, and you probably will not get a routine answer. “Today, I’m working and I’m fine,” she said on a recent Tuesday. “Saturday and Sunday, I was bedridden. Long Covid is a roller coaster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Satz and Dan Edelstein
title: By Abandoning Civics, Colleges Helped Create the Culture Wars
description: How the failure of universities to provide a civic education has resulted in an intolerance of ideas.
content: Free speech is once again a flashpoint on college campuses. This year has seen at least 20 instances in which students or faculty members attempted to rescind invitations or to silence speakers. In March, law school students at our own institution made national news when they shouted down a conservative federal judge, Kyle Duncan. And by signing legislation that undermines academic freedom in Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis is carrying out what is effectively a broad assault against higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky Replaces Defense Minister, Citing Need for ‘New Approaches’
description: The fate of the defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, had been the subject of increasing speculation in Ukraine. It was the biggest shake-up in Ukraine’s government since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday that he was replacing his minister of defense, the biggest shake-up in the leadership of Ukraine’s war effort since Russia’s full-scale invasion began, citing the need for “new approaches” after more than 18 months of conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘That First Subway Ride Was Punctuated by a Whooshing Sound’
description: A journey to the World’s Fair, condolences from a stranger and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Rape Cases Seize Italy’s Attention and Expose Cultural Rifts
description: A summer of horrific crimes, including the gang rapes of two young girls, has put a new focus on the country’s attitudes toward women and the amplifying role of social media.
content: Shattered glass surrounds the abandoned swimming pool, along with dilapidated benches, broken tiles and a single dirty mattress. Local police officers have identified the forsaken spot as one of the places where they say two young girls were repeatedly raped by a gang of their peers, all residents of the Italian town of Caivano, on the outskirts of Naples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Meet Fabian Nelson, Mississippi’s First Openly L.G.B.T.Q. Legislator
description: Mr. Nelson, 38, won a Democratic primary runoff on Tuesday in a blue district. He talked to The New York Times about the significance of being the first — but why he never focused on it on the trail.
content: Only two states in the nation, Louisiana and Mississippi, have never elected an openly L.G.B.T.Q. lawmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Belle Boggs
title: How Rescuing Frogs Inspires the Way I Fight for Change
description: Local battles are just as important as national ones.
content: During the first spring of the pandemic, my two daughters and I taught ourselves to rescue frogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At the U.S. Open, It Feels Like the Fourth of July
description: It has been several decades since American tennis players dominated en masse this deep into their home Grand Slam tournament. The American tennis party looks to continue for at least a few more days.
content: A decade or so ago, back when Tommy Paul, Taylor Fritz and Frances Tiafoe were rowdy teenagers raising hell at the United States Tennis Association dormitories in Florida, they dreamed that days like Sunday at the U.S. Open would eventually come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Forever Wandering
description: Tom Pepper and Zhouqin Burnikel’s Labor Day crossword is not to scale … or is it?
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
title: Amid Struggles, Turkey Finds Heroes in Its Women’s Volleyball Team
description: Turkey is basking in the success of players it calls “Sultans of the Net,” seeing paragons of female empowerment in a country grappling with multiple crises.
content: As the volleyball game neared its end, thousands of fans watching on giant screens in an Istanbul park rose to their feet and fell silent. The ball soared, a Turkish player set it up near the net, and her teammate spiked it. Her Italian opponents blocked the shot but knocked the ball out of bounds, handing victory to the Turks and causing the crowd to erupt into chants of “Turkey! Turkey! Turkey!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi Dissident’s Brother Is Sentenced to Death in Social Media Case
description: Under a crackdown on dissent by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, prosecutors accused a retired teacher of treason after he criticized the ruling family.
content: A court in Saudi Arabia has sentenced to death the brother of an exiled dissident, convicting him of disloyalty to the kingdom’s rulers in a case built around anonymous social media accounts where he shared criticism of the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: New Novels Brimming With Murder, Jazz and Sumptuous Sweets
description: Our crime columnist recommends four September books.
content: Ragnar Jonasson has long been one of Iceland’s commercial successes, selling more than 3 million copies of his crime novels there. REYKJAVIK (Minotaur, 367 pp., $28) his first collaboration with Katrin Jakobsdottir — the country’s current prime minister, by the way — qualifies as a breakout: seamlessly plotted, with terrific characters and plenty of surprising, earned twists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: To Experience Paris Up Close and Personal, Plunge Into a Public Pool
description: Swimming in Paris is a full-on cultural experience, offering intimate views into the French psyche, which is on near-naked display in the swimming lanes, locker rooms and (mostly coed) showers.
content: I slip into the water and push off quickly before the man swimming like a breast-stroking porpoise gets any closer. Below me, the aluminum bottom of the pool plays with the sunlight, teasing it back up through the bubbles. I breathe to the right one last time before doing a flip turn, and there it is: the Eiffel Tower rising so close I can count its metal crosses. The pool windows offer an unobstructed, third-story view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: New Hampshire Voters Like Ramaswamy, but More as a No. 2
description: At campaign stops across the state, the political newcomer has drawn big crowds and praise from voters. But some wonder if he needs more political seasoning.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, the only top-polling presidential candidate to hit the campaign trail over Labor Day weekend, is enjoying the attention of his newfound status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: South African Inquiry Rebuts U.S. Charge on Russian Arms
description: A government investigation about a Russian ship contradicts U.S. accusations that South Africa provided arms to fight Ukraine, President Cyril Ramaphosa said. But a government report won’t be released, he added.
content: An investigation by the South African government has concluded that weapons were not loaded onto a Russian vessel under American sanctions that docked near Cape Town last year, contradicting accusations by U.S. officials that South Africa had provided arms for the war in Ukraine, President Cyril Ramaphosa said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: 85,000 Highchairs Recalled After Reports of Two Dozen Falls
description: The company that makes the chairs has received reports of falls resulting in nearly a dozen injuries, such as bruises or scratches.
content: More than 85,000 highchairs sold online and at retailers across North America are being recalled after reports of two dozen falls related to the chairs, according to federal regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Crisis-Hit British Museum Names Interim Director
description: Mark Jones, a former leader of the Victoria and Albert Museum, is set to take over with a remit to restore confidence after a theft scandal.
content: Almost three weeks after the British Museum was plunged into crisis by the revelation of thefts from its storerooms, the London institution said it would come under new leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn-Olaf Jones, Anna Betts and Amanda Holpuch
title: Amid Rain and Mud, Climactic ‘Burn’ Is Delayed at Burning Man Fest
description: Officials urged campers to conserve food and water on Sunday, as the police investigated one death. The annual burning of a manlike figure was postponed.
content: The torrential rains that turned roads and grounds into muck and left thousands of people stranded at the Burning Man festival also put off the climax of the carefree celebration of art, music and counterculture: The annual burning of a manlike figure will not happen on Sunday night as had been planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Leaping ‘Into the Next Unknown’: Robert Lyons on the End of New Ohio Theater
description: The handwriting on the company’s wall, in chalk, was traced by a closing night crowd sharing memories of more than 30 years of landmarks and larks.
content: The last performance of the last show at the 74-seat New Ohio Theater, on Christopher Street in Manhattan’s West Village, was “Ultra Left Violence,” a poetical, political, work-in-progress play by the company’s artistic director, Robert Lyons. Wrapping up the New Ohio’s final Ice Factory festival on Aug. 12, it was thrillingly, even touchingly, weird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Manhattan Prosecutors Seize a Bronze Bust Valued at $5 Million
description: The life-size sculpture, believed to represent the daughter of the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, was in the Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts.
content: An ancient Roman statue believed to depict the daughter of the emperor Marcus Aurelius, and valued at $5 million, has been seized by New York officials as part of a nationwide investigation into antiquities looted from what is now Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: Why David Fincher Wanted Michael Fassbender to Look ‘Dorky’
description: Movies are full of glamorous hit men. For “The Killer,” the director put his star in a bucket hat: “The $3,000 suit seems like it’s played out.”
content: It’s been 24 years since David Fincher brought one of his movies to the Venice Film Festival, and the last time, things didn’t go so well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Auto Strike Looms, Threatening to Shut Detroit’s Big 3
description: With their contract expiring Sept. 14, the United Auto Workers and the companies are far apart in talks. A walkout could take a big economic toll.
content: The United Auto Workers union and the three Detroit automakers have less than two weeks to negotiate a new labor contract, and a strike of some sort seems increasingly likely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Serge F. Kovaleski and Leanne Abraham
title: How a New City Council Map of L.A. Turned Into a Political Brawl
description: Blatant political gerrymandering occurs in cities across the country, many of them run by Democrats. In Los Angeles, a scandal over a racist recording was only the tip of the iceberg.
content: Nithya Raman turned into a political celebrity almost overnight when she emerged as the face of a rising progressive vanguard to campaign for the Los Angeles City Council in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Constant Méheut
title: Russia Attacks Ukrainian River Port, Injuring at Least 2
description: The assault in the Odesa region came as Ukraine’s president said two more ships had traveled through a temporary corridor established by Kyiv after Moscow pulled out of the Black Sea grain deal.
content: Russian forces launched waves of drones at the Odesa region of southern Ukraine in an hourslong overnight assault, officials said on Sunday, the latest bombardment to target port infrastructure since Moscow pulled out of a deal allowing safe passage for Ukrainian grain through the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Furniture Shop’s Bland Facade Conceals a Trove of Tennis History
description: In Mineola, N.Y., Rosini Furniture Service restores and refinishes, but its owner’s true passion is the racket sport.
content: Rosini Furniture Service is a business that seems like a front for a tennis museum.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America’s Shift Away From Religion
description: Readers react to a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Making driverless taxis accessible; Fulton County jail conditions; what makes a good person.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Aguirre
title: An Unexpected Hotbed of Y.A. Authors: Utah
description: A tight-knit community of young-adult writers who belong to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has yielded smashes like “Twilight.” But religious doctrine can clash with creative freedoms.
content: American book-reading habits have been in decline for decades, but you wouldn’t know it from sitting in on a young-adult literature class held last winter at Brigham Young University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Ban Online Porn for Kids
description: A Supreme Court ruling from the early days of the internet is woefully out of date.
content: New Yorkers above a certain age remember the old Times Square. If you created a list of words to describe it, “depraved” would be near the top. Peep shows, adult bookstores and live sex shows stretched on for block after block. But New York was hardly alone; major cities across the country had their own red-light districts. When I started my freshman year at a college in Nashville, the city’s Lower Broadway was a miniature version of Times Square. To reach the tiny, tourist-friendly sectors of downtown, you had to drive down Lower Broadway, past peep shows, strip clubs and open prostitution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Says It Thwarted Night Attack on Bridge
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 3, 2023.
content: “I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimeter by themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francisco Goldman
title: Guatemala’s Democracy Is Dead. Long Live Democracy!
description: An anti-graft candidate no one expected to win prevails in a landslide.
content: When I visited Guatemala in May 2022, the feeling of hopelessness was palpable. The government of President Alejandro Giammattei had unleashed a ferocious persecution of anti-corruption justice officials. That February, Virginia Laparra, a prosecutor in the Special Prosecutor’s Office Against Impunity, had been arrested along with four other anti-corruption lawyers; they were all put in the same cell at the Mariscal Zavala military prison in Guatemala City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Grilled Peaches With Dukkah to Savor the Last of Summer
description: With Ruth Reichl’s giant chocolate cake (actual name) to soothe back-to-school stresses.
content: Hello from Atlanta, where school started a month ago and we are deep into packing lunches, working hard and trying to ignore the recent courthouse shenanigans that seem to keep Georgia on everybody’s mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Woman Gives Birth Alone in a Tennessee Jail Cell
description: The woman had sought medical help for over an hour before giving birth, officials said. The episode, which has drawn criticism, highlights issues about the incarceration of pregnant women.
content: A woman gave birth alone in a jail cell in Tennessee on Tuesday after seeking medical attention for more than an hour, the authorities said, raising questions about the care provided to the woman and her baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Trapped in Mud, Burning Man Attendees Are Told to Conserve Food
description: As the festival in the remote Nevada desert became encased in mud after heavy rains on Friday night, the police opened an investigation on Saturday into the death of an attendee.
content: As thousands of attendees at the Burning Man festival in a remote stretch of the Black Rock Desert in Nevada were told on Saturday to conserve food, water and fuel after heavy rainfall trapped them in thick mud, the police opened an investigation into the death of a person during the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean McFate
title: Prigozhin’s Real Legacy: The Mercenary Blueprint
description: The Wagner group will serve as a model for other mercenaries ready to muscle in to resource-rich territories.
content: The death of Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Wagner mercenary chief, has set off intense speculation over the future of the world’s most dangerous private army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: In Venezuela, a Mission Amid Heartbreak
description: After studying journalism abroad, a photographer returned home, where economic collapse needed documenting.
content: Night had already fallen as the reporter Isayen Herrera and I drove through stretches of plains in eastern Venezuela last November. As we came around a bend in the road, the sky suddenly filled  with light. Everything around us was tinted orange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Soprano Ailyn Pérez Doesn’t Feel Like a Beginner Anymore
description: Long a rising star, she is getting a new Metropolitan Opera production built around her, the house’s first Spanish-language show in nearly a century.
content: Ailyn Pérez didn’t get a chance to see the billboards in New York: the Metropolitan Opera’s advertisements for its coming season, featuring a portrait of her in spectral whites, her eyes closed as she comes face to face with a butterfly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monday Briefing: China’s Mobilization Against Espionage
description: Also, India’s first solar mission.
content: China’s ruling Communist Party is enlisting ordinary people to guard against perceived threats to the country, in a campaign that blurs the line between vigilance and paranoia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Slow Death of the Sun-Seeking Summer Vacation
description: How climate change and the resulting calamities are killing our notion of the hallowed sun-seeking summer vacation.
content: The images emerging from the Mediterranean in late July resembled a fixture of the evening news: the desperate crowd fleeing adversity. But these fugitives walking along hot tarmac or waiting to board rescue boats in the night were not the displaced victims of a broken republic. These were pleasure seekers in flip-flops and tank tops, toting beach bags over sun-tanned shoulders, retreating from a glowing sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Sergio Olmos and Eileen Sullivan
title: Maui Sent an Evacuation Alert. Why Did So Few People Get It?
description: The Hawaii wildfire offered insights into the promises and shortcomings of a wireless alert system that relies on cellphones for emergency warnings.
content: As fire was billowing through residential neighborhoods in the Hawaii town of Lahaina last month, emergency managers for Maui County sent out an evacuation alert that would blare on the cellphones of anyone near the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Graver
title: Conjuring a 17th-Century Witch Hunt, With Echoes of Our Own Day
description: Inspired by events in East Anglia, England, in 1645, “The Witching Tide,” by Margaret Meyer, evokes the climate of fear and accusation that grips a town with the arrival of a “witchfinder.”
content: In a 1996 essay, “Why I Wrote ‘The Crucible,’” the playwright Arthur Miller describes how the 1692 witch trials in Salem, Mass., offered a way to examine the torments of 1950s McCarthyism in the aftermath of World War II. “There was magic all around,” Miller writes. “The politics of alien conspiracy soon dominated political discourse and bid fair to wipe out any other issue. How could one deal with such enormities in a play? ‘The Crucible’ was an act of desperation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Three American Lives Forever Changed by a Weapon Now Being Sent to Ukraine
description: The mother of a Marine and two veterans who served in Iraq reflect on the U.S. decision to send failure-prone shells to help the Ukrainian military battle Russia.
content: In the summer of 2003, not long after U.S. forces had taken Baghdad, a group of Marines was clearing unexploded ordnance in central Iraq when one of the small grenades littering the ground detonated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Success of Mormon Fantasy Writers
description: The faith has made successful young adult authors, thanks to a unique blend of support for religious writers and an emphasis on family entertainment.
content: An epic origin story, a charismatic leader, a generational saga: Is this the description of a fantasy novel, or a religion’s history?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Florida’s Congressional Map Illegally Hurt Black Voters, Judge Rules
description: Under the ruling, Florida is forbidden to use the map in the 2024 election, and state legislators are required to draw a new one. But the decision can be appealed.
content: A Florida judge struck down the state’s congressional map on Saturday, ruling that it violated the Florida Constitution by diminishing the influence of Black voters, and ordering the State Legislature “to enact a new map which complies with the Florida Constitution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Netanyahu Calls to Expel Unauthorized Immigrants After Eritreans Clash
description: The Israeli prime minister’s remarks revived a debate about the fate of thousands of asylum seekers after hundreds of opposing Eritrean groups faced off in Tel Aviv this weekend.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday called for the deportation of all unauthorized immigrants from Israel, a day after a riot in Tel Aviv between rival groups of Eritreans left more than 100 people injured.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 3, 2023.
content: An article published on Aug. 20 about housing in Colorado re­ferred incorrectly to a measure of home values in Summit County. The “residential actual value” of homes in the county increased by 63 percent from June 30, 2020, to June 30, 2022, based on informa­tion gathered by the state from the Colorado Assessors’ Associa­tion; that was not the increase in residential property prices in the county in the past year. The article also referred impre­cisely to conservation easements. The legal agreements can be between property owners and land trusts, not only property owners and local governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Nathan Louis Jackson, Writer for the Theater and TV, Dies at 44
description: He wrote plays that tackled big issues like the death penalty and gun violence. He also wrote for series including the superhero saga “Luke Cage.”
content: Nathan Louis Jackson, an acclaimed playwright who grappled with serious issues like the death penalty, homophobia and gun violence — and was also known for his work on television shows like “Luke Cage,” a Netflix series about a Black superhero — died on Aug. 22 at his home in Lenexa, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City. He was 44.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Ken Bensinger
title: Judge Vacates Convictions in Bribery Case Over Soccer Broadcast Deals
description: Hernán López, a former Fox employee, and an Argentine sports marketing company had been convicted of participating in a bribery scheme to secure rights to widely viewed tournaments.
content: Less than six months after a federal jury convicted a former Fox employee and an Argentine sports marketing company of participating in a scheme to pay bribes in exchange for lucrative soccer broadcasting contracts, a judge in Brooklyn vacated the convictions on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Anderson Cooper Is Still Learning to Live With Loss
description: “The fact that I’m 56 and still realizing I never grieved when I was 11? That’s ridiculous,” says the CNN anchor.
content: “The fact that I’m 56 and still realizing I never grieved when I was 11? That’s ridiculous,” says the CNN anchor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Cook Escobar and Christine Zhang
title: A Summer of Strikes
description: See how a wave of labor activity in the United States this summer compares with decades past.
content: See how a wave of labor activity in the United States this summer compares with decades past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Mira Rojanasakul
title: Big Farms and Flawless Fries Are Gulping Water in the Land of 10,000 Lakes
description: When Minnesota farmers cranked up their powerful wells, they blew through state limits. Thirsty crops included corn, soybeans and perfect, fry-friendly potatoes.
content: When Minnesota farmers cranked up their powerful wells, they blew through state limits. Thirsty crops included corn, soybeans and perfect, fry-friendly potatoes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, September 3, 2023
description: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
content: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso
title: Heavy Rain Strands Thousands at Burning Man Festival
description: Attendees braced for more rainfall after heavy downpours turned the festival grounds into thick mud, limiting access to the site in the Nevada desert.
content: Attendees braced for more rainfall after heavy downpours turned the festival grounds into thick mud, limiting access to the site in the Nevada desert.
source.name: The New York Times
